subsection.title: Products of Variables
subsection.p: In Section 5.1, we learned to simplify the sum of two algebraic expressions by combining like terms. In this section we see how to multiply algebraic expressions.

Recall that we can simplify a product such as 3(2x) because 3(2x) = 2x+2x+2x = 6x~~~~~~~~~~~~\blert{\text{Three terms}} This calculation is actually an application of the associative property: 3(2x) = (3 \cdot 2)x = 6x In a similar way, we can simplify the product (3b)(4b) by applying the commutative and associative properties: (3b)(4b) = 3 \cdot b \cdot 4 \cdot b = 3 \cdot 4 \cdot b \cdot b = (3 \cdot 4) \cdot (b \cdot b) = 12b^2

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: You can convince yourself that (3b)(4b) is equivalent to 12b^2 by substituting some values for b; for example, if b=\alert{2}, then (3 \cdot \alert{2})(4 \cdot \alert{2})=(6)(8) = 48~~~~\text{and}~~~~12(\alert{2})^2=12 \cdot 4 = 48
The commutative and associative properties tell us that we can multiply the factors of a product in any order.

li.p: We apply the commutative property: (5a)(-3a) = 5(-3) \cdot a \cdot a = -15a^2
To cube an expression means to multiply three copies of the expression together: (2x)^3 = (2x)(2x)(2x) = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x = 8x^3
We rearrange the factors to group each variable together: (xy^2)(4x^2) = x \cdot y \cdot y \cdot 4 \cdot x \cdot x = 4 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot y \cdot y = 4x^3y^2

warning.p: When we add like terms, we do not change the variable in the terms; we combine the coefficients. For example, 3a+2a=5a When we multiply expressions, we multiply the coefficients and we multiply the variables: 3a(2a) = 3(2) \cdot a \cdot a = 6a^2

answer.p: The first expression is a sum and the second is a product.

subsection.title: Using the Distributive Law
subsection.p: We can use the areas of rectangles to investigate products of algebraic expressions. Recall that we find the area of a rectangle by multiplying its length times its width, A=lw. We have already used rectangles to visualize the distributive law. Here are some examples.

statement.p: State the distributive law, and explain what it means.

answer.p: a(b+c)=ab+ac~~~"Distribute" the multiplication to each term inside parentheses.

subsection.p: At this stage it will be helpful to introduce some terminology.

ul.li: An algebraic expression with only one term, such as 2x^3, is called a monomialmonomial.
An expression with two terms, such as x^2-16, is called a binomialbinomial.
An expression with three terms is a trinomialtrinomialtrinomialquadratic trinomial.
The expression ax^2+bx+c is thus called a quadratic trinomialquadratic trinomial, because it involves the square of the variable.

warning.p:
Notice the difference between (3a)(2a) and 3a(2+a):
(3a)(2a) is the product of two monomials, and we use the commutative property to simplify it: (3a)(2a)= 3 \cdot a \cdot 2 \cdot a =3 \cdot 2 \cdot a \cdot a = 6a^2
3a(2+a) is the product of a monomial and a binomial, and we use the distributive law to simplify it: 3a(2+a)=3a(2)+3a(a)=6a+3a^2

statement.p: Explain the terms monomial, binomial, and trinomial.

answer.p: Having one term, two terms, or three terms.

assemblage.p: Our goal in this Lesson is to understand products of binomials. We can use rectangles to illustrate, or model, the product of two binomials. The rectangles do not have to be drawn exactly to scale; they are merely tools for visualizing products. With a small stretch of the imagination, we can use rectangles to represent negative numbers as well.

subsection.title: The Four Terms in a Binomial Product
subsection.p: Using a rectangle to multiply binomials illustrates how the distributive law works. Analyzing the rectangle method will help us in a later Lesson, when we reverse the process to factor a quadratic trinomial. Let us take a closer look at the example above.

assemblage.title: Look Closer

sidebyside.p: In we computed the product (x-4)(x+6). The top row of the rectangle corresponds to x(x+6)=x^2+6x and the bottom row corresponds to -4(x+6)=-4x-24

assemblage.p: Thus, we multiply each term of the first binomial by each term of the second binomial, resulting in four multiplications in all: (x-4)(x+6)=x^2+6x-4x-24 Each term of the product corresponds to the area of one of the four sub-rectangles, as shown below.

subsection.p:
The letters \blert{\text{F, O, I, L}} indicate the four steps in computing the product:FOIL (terms of binomial product)
\blert{\text{F}} stands for the product of the \blert{\text{First}} terms in each binomial.
\blert{\text{O}} stands for the product of the \blert{\text{Outer}} terms.
\blert{\text{I}} stands for the product of the \blert{\text{Inner}} terms.
\blert{\text{L}} stands for the product of the \blert{\text{Last}} terms.

ul.li: The quadratic term in the product comes from the First terms.
The linear or x-term of the product is the sum of Outer and Inner.
The constant term of the product comes from the Last terms.
